support.p: This is an ivory seal, and according to Sankalia (1960: 202): “the seal has a circular flat base and a flat and round hold. The diameter of the base on which the letters and the various symbols are carved in the negative is 15mm. The whole base is divided into four compartments. The latter are bounded by margins with a rope-like pattern. Short lines decorate the periphery. The four compartments bear four symbols, some associated with Buddhism and some found on coins. The left hand top compartment has a svastika with angular arms. The right hand top compartment has the triratna; the left hand bottom has probably a pair of hooded serpents or might be śrīvatsa, and the right hand bottom compartment has a symbol representing the triangle-headed banner laid horizontally.”

origin.origPlace: Nevāsā, found in layer 9 of Trench E during the 1954–1956 excavations.

div.p: The edition is based on Sankalia (1960: 202–203). I have identified Kṛṣṇa with the Sātavāhana king, as this seal was found in the same layer as early Sātavāhana coins at Nevasa, but note that there is no identifying information.
